results.title: Land rights views: Number 8, July 1997 (A)
results.creator_credit: Northern Land Council and Northern Land Council Media Unit
results.brief_description: A yearly magazine program dealing with issues associated with the Northern Land Council. This edition includes reports on the Jawoyn ‘Five Year Plan’, the Crocker Island seas native title claim, the Wik decision, a social impact study in the Kakadu region, the fight to save Railway Dam in Darwin and the ‘Black economy’ in the Top End. Music from various Aboriginal acts is also featured.

results.title: Land of tomorrow
results.creator_credit: Australian National Airways, Cinesound Movietone and Frank Coffey
results.brief_description: A tribute is made to Bristol Aeroplane Ltd, manufacturers of the Bristol Type 170 “Freighter”, the aeroplane that made beef by air an economic feasibility mainly in the Kimberley region of Western Australia.

results.title: Land of the tiger
results.brief_description: Presented by Valmik Thapar, this is a celebration of the incredible diversity of wildlife across the Indian subcontinent. It explores some of the most fascinating habitats in the natural world.. from the icy vastness of the Himalayas to the lush forest dominated by the world’s largest tiger population; from vast plains and the beauty of the Rajasthan deserts to mighty rivers and the superabundant life of the oceans.

results.title: Land of the tiger
results.brief_description: A rare and fascinating study of the enormous jungle cats. The film features spectacular footage of tigers stalking their prey, caring for their young, swimming, playing and fighting as well as glimpses of other animals with which the tiger shares its domain.

results.title: Land of the sleeping giant
results.creator_credit: Associated World Public Relations, Yalumba Vineyards and Colin Ballantyne
results.brief_description: The Yalumba Winery in the Barossa Valley, South Australia. Aboriginal legends of a sleeping giant surround the country where Samuel Smith planted the first vines in 1849. His descendants now own a large modern winery in Anguston. Many varieties of grapes are harvested, and the whole process of making, blending and bottling the various wines and spirits is shown. Scientific tests are carried out throughout and the brandies are subject to Government inspection. Narrated by Charles “Bud” Tingwell.

results.title: Land of the morning star
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Janet Bell and Mark Worth
results.brief_description: Writer/director Mark Worth has created a fascinating documentary about the oft forgotten western region of the island of Papua (also known as Netherlands New Guinea, West Papua, Irian Jaya and Papua). This film provides insight into the history of “West Papua” and its flag “The Morning Star”. Currently ruled by Indonesia, the film details political activist’s struggle for independence and their forced exile from a climate of fervent Indonesian nationalism. The film reveals a turbulent history in which Australia, the US and the UN have played a part. Narrated by Rachel Griffiths, music composed by David Bridie. A National Interest Program from Film Australia produced with assistance from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

results.title: Land of the long weekend
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Susan Ardill and Sue Brooks
results.brief_description: Australia was the first country in the world to have a 40 hour working week, which accompanied by an array of public holidays, led to the identification of Australia as the working man’s paradise, a mythical land of the long weekend. This film examines how, in the face of deregulation and restructuring, long term unemployment and 24 hour trading, Australians have structured and restructured their time. Will Australians, drunk on sunshine, rally in time to save their precious weekend - or has it, in the drive to be flexible and efficient, already been lost?

results.title: Land of the long day
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Michael Spencer and Douglas Wilkinson
results.brief_description: During the short Arctic summer on Baffin Island, the native Inuit enjoys four months of continuous daylight. But it is not time for relaxation, for provision must be made for the long, cold winter night ahead. In this film Idlouk, an Inuit hunter, tells of his life in the northern land. We watch as he stalks the seal so vital to his existance, and as he and other hunters set out in kayaks to harpoon the white whale and the narwhal. At camp we meet his wife, children and aged parents, each of whom has work to do in the unceasing struggle for survival in this harsh land. (Six awards. including Chicago; Durban; Cortina d’Ampezzo)

results.title: Land of the Lightning Brothers
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Janet Bell and David Roberts
results.brief_description: In the sandstone country, southwest of Katherine in the Northern Territory, lies a spectacular concentration of Aboriginal rock art. The Lightning Brothers, Yagjadbula and Jabaringa, with wide dark eyes and dramatically striped bodies are ancestral beings who in the Dreamtime helped shape the traditional land of the Wardaman Aboriginal people. This multi-award winning film shows how the Wardaman people see the Lightning Brothers as part of their living culture, and it features the music of “Gondwanaland”. Narrated by Bob Maza.

results.title: Land of the hornbill
results.creator_credit: Malayan Film Unit, B.H. Hipkins and Ow Kheng Law
results.brief_description: A picture of life in the colony of Sarawak, youngest of the British protectorates and the home of the head-hunting Dyaks. With the discovery and production of oil, much industrial progress has been made - progress which often contrasts sharply with the ancient crafts. The film shows the living conditions, the production of sago by old and new methods, the growing of pepper, and the immensely important oil industry.
